position.marginalia_text: Nunq[uam] ta[e]deat Domenici, aut Gandini: aut ullius Monopragmatici.

marginalia.translation: May we never become tired of Domenichi, Gandino, or any other single-skilled man.

position.marginalia_text:
Consilium Medicum Eobani Hessi, Poeta[e] Physici, et Homerici. Vtere Conuiuis non tristibus: vtere amicis, Quos Chelys, et risus, et ioca salsa iuuant.
Dominus Thomas Morus, summus Anglia[e] Cancellarius; sed ut homo ingeniosissimus, ita valdè vrbanus, et perfacetus; solebat illud per vulgatum subinde repetere: Dum sumus in Mundo, viuiamus corde jocundo. Idem pro eo, quod dici solet: Sic transit gloria Mundi: solebat dicere: Sic transit moria glundi: quasi alludens ad Moria[e] Encomiu[m]; aut vulgare illud, Stultorum plena sunt Omnia. Nam festiuus vir, Luciani ingenio delectabatur; et sa[e]pè agebat Democritu[m]. Nec tantus

Socrates, quantus ille ingeniosus vir; semper hilaris in omni societate Ciuili. Etiam mortem oppetiturus, iocabatur affatim; et ridebat omnes, et omnia, pra[e]ter suam causam. Amabat Bacchu[m]: sed eundem Janum, Osirim, Apollinem. Euohe.

marginalia.translation:
The medical advice of Eobanus Hessus, Homeric poet and natural philosopher: enjoy gatherings (that aren't gloomy), enjoy friends who are delighted by the lyre, laughter, and witty jokes.
Master Thomas Moore, High Chancellor of England, though he was a most ingenius man, was also very urbane and incredibly witty. He used to repeat constanty that common expression: "While we are in the world, let us live with a happy heart." Likewise, for that which is normally said, "Sic transit gloria mundi," he would say, "Sic transit moria glundi," as if alluding to 'The praise of folly'. Or that common phrase, "All things are full of fools." Indeed he was a lively man, delighted by the genius of Lucian, and often he acted like Democritus. And the ingenuity of this was was found not so much in Socratic irony, as in remaining always cheerful in every civil society. Even when he was about to meet death, he joked continuously, and he laughed at everything and everyone before his trial. He loved Bacchus, but also Janus, Osiris, Apolllo. Euohe!
Homer's laughter-loving Venus is fond of laughing.

position.marginalia_text: Vnicus mundi magnes, est Animus. Nec ullus adamas tam penetrax: nec ipse philosophorum Lapis tam multiplicabundus.

marginalia.translation: The sole lodestone of the world is the Soul. No steel is as penetrating, nor philosophers' stone as full of reproductive power.

position.marginalia_text: At nihil tale feci, aut dixi: meam dedecus. At plus faciam: mea Apologia. At iam feci: mea dignitas. Eudromus.

marginalia.translation: But I never did or said anything so great: this is my disgrace. But I shall do more: this is my apology. But now it is done: this is my dignity. Eudromus.
